Art, Science, and Fear Benjamin C. Pierce University of Pennsylvania Abstract Scientists and artists 
share a conviction that key elements of their work creativity, craft, analysis, intuition are somehow 
deeply similar. Most Onward! participants will have a clear sense of the scienti.c variants of these 
qualities, and of what it takes to manifest them in our day-to-day work as researchers and software designers. 
This talk looks at how ideas are developed and re.ned in the making of visual art, how the same qualities 
especially creativity, the most ineffable come into play, and how artists and scientists grapple with 
the various fears that beset creative work. Categories and Subject Descriptors D.m [Software]: Miscella­neous 
General Terms Design Keywords Creativity, photography Bio Benjamin C. Pierce is Professor of Computer 
and Information Sci­ence at the University of Pennsylvania. Before Penn, he served on the faculty at 
Indiana University and held research fellow­ships at Cambridge University, the University of Edinburgh, 
and INRIA-Roquencourt. He received his Ph.D. in Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University in 1991. 
As a computer scientist,1 his interests center on programming languages, static type systems, computer 
security and privacy, con­current and distributed programming, and synchronization tech­nologies. His 
books include the widely used graduate text Types and Programming Languages. He is also the lead designer 
of the popular Unison .le synchronizer. As a photographer,2 his primary concerns are abstraction and 
the human .gure sometimes in isolation, often in combina­tion. His mentors include Arno Minkkinen, Sean 
Kearnen, Becky Young, and Gabe Martinez. Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). 1 http://www.cis.upenn.edu/~bcpierce
